div.p: 1. The current general second person pronouns are rǔ 汝 in informal contexts, and in polite contexts zǐ 子.
2. The current informal pronoun is rǔ 汝, and this word is commonly used in imperatives.

3. Ěr 爾 is another informal second person pronoun, and the word is not generally used in imperatives.

4. Ruò 若 is a poetic/archaising second person pronoun that went out of current use in Tang (待考）times.

5. Jūn 君 addresses superiors as well as equals formally, and politely.

6. Qīng 卿 is probably stylistically colloquial and addresses inferiors informally.

7. Dà wáng 大王 is the polite formal address to any king, small or powerful.

8. Wú zǐ 吾子, extremely common in the Zuozhuan, is respectful and honorific, but in a communicativ and sometimes even intimate mode: ·鄭玄注："吾子，相貌之辞。
HUMAN AFFAIRS 37. MALE ADULT POLITE REFERENCE TERME 男性尊稱。
公，位於姓氏後或用於面稱。
子，特指業師；一般用於敘稱或面稱，亦可位於姓氏後。
君，位於姓氏或封號之後、人名之前；面稱時可用於上對下或下對上。
卿，有親昵色彩。位於姓氏後，可用於敘稱或面稱；獨用時用於上對下面稱。
兄台 (lit) is a ceremonial traditionalist address to a spiritual brother.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

sense.def: you, my lord; you, my lord and father ZUO
you (can also refer occasionally to the deceased, in prayers)
爾眾"you my many servitors": you
BUDDH: you, the senior fellow monk; you my elder brother
You (the duke); later: colloquial in informal conversation: you
you, my ruler; your lordship; you, my master

entry.def: The current general second person pronouns are rǔ 汝 and in polite contexts zǐ 子.
The current general second person pronouns are rǔ 汝 and in polite contexts zǐ 子.

sense.def: e.g. 汝"you (my son), familiar, informal you
you (personal first person plural pronoun being followed by N in apposition which specifies the scope of the plural) 汝四子 you the four children
you (referring to a non-human - sometimes even abstract - object)
you (addressed to a non-human sometimes even inanimate object)
quasi-reader: you, as if the reader of the text (which was, however, taken over from a spoken setting)

entry.def: The current general second person pronouns are rǔ 汝 and in polite contexts zǐ 子.

sense.def: generally honorific pron: you; plural: you gentlemen
you (the reference being poetically unspecified in context)
(of wife to her husband, as it used to be in French and in German, etc) you
you, official SSXY 若蒙官; also: you, my father-in-law; you, esteemed person
you, my husband's mother; you my mother

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

sense.def: colloquial: this N > you N (used in derogatory and insulting expressions when the speaker avoids to address the dialogue partner directly)
you, monk on the upper seat; you, monk sitting on the seat of honour
you, the prince (not necessarily of the same country)
you, my uncle (literally: the younge brother of my father), traditional address of the Son of Heaven to any of the feudal lords with the same family name
you, my Marshal; you the Marshal
you, being a big state; you on behalf of your state
you, my child; you, young man!
you, little sister of my husband
you, the mountain-dweller; you, the recluse (Tang)
BUDDH: master older brother > you, the senior fellow monk; you, the senior fellow apprentice (the semi-pronoun is occasionally contrasted with the humble first person pronoun 專甲 in ZTJ)
BUDDH: master younger brother > you, the junior fellow monk (master); compare 師兄

entry.def: you, lord of the house SSXY

sense.def: emphatic second person pronoun (followed by a quantifying apposition)

bibl.title: Studies in the Language of Zǔtáng jí 祖堂集

note.p: This is a polite term used by a monk when addressing a lay-supporter of Buddhism. Typically, the address is directed towards persons of often considerable influence and wealth (e.g. the emperor) who actively support the monasteries with money or material goods.

sense.def: BUDDH: you, the lay-supporter; you the Dānapati (this semi-pronoun is typically used by monks when addressing influential and wealthy lay Buddhists who support monasteries and monks with material goods or money)
BUDDH: Mister Dharma > you the person involved in the Dharma, you, the monk
BUDDH: elder brother > you, the senior monk
BUDDH: you, the old recluse, you the venerable hermit
BUDDH: ?? you, the teacher; you, the master
colloquial and derogatory: you, this fellow
you people, monks and laymen alike
of you, followers of the Way
you, emminent monk; you, senior monk

bibl.title: Studies in the Language of Zǔtáng jí 祖堂集

note.p: This semi-pronoun has a frequency of ca. 100 occurrences in ZTJ. It is actually not clear whether it should be regarded as honorific semi-pronoun since it is usually used by the master when addressing a disciple, often in a mocking or even derogatory tone.

sense.def: BUDDH: you, the teacher SANSKRIT ācārya
BUDDH: this is a derogatory expression for monks: you, the monk
you, who renounced home; you monks
you (coming from a good family), you sons of good families; you gentlemen (originally used by Buddha when addressing his disciples)
you, my dear friend and teacher
you, the great and accomplished person
colloquial and derogatory: you, this domestic animal

(Read: zhèi..., a pronunciation still not recognised in 廣韻 because that book is concerned with readings in literary texts only and does not have such readings as hái for 還 although the word was current in Sòng times.)(You) this old fellow (derogatory)
BUDDH: you, the unimportant/insignicant mountain recluse
to you; from you; than you etc.
